Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story: I sat on the edge of the couch, my stepbrother’s laughter echoing from the kitchen as the rest of the family bustled around, preparing for the holiday dinner. My stepmom called out, “Come help us set the table! We’re all doing this together.” I knew how important these moments were—blending into this new family, showing up, being present. But I glanced at the clock. In five minutes, I had planned a quiet ten-minute meditation, a practice I’d promised myself I wouldn’t skip, especially on stressful days like this. My Buddhist teacher always said mindfulness was most needed when life felt chaotic. Yet, here I was, torn. If I slipped away for meditation, I’d miss the laughter, the chance to bond, maybe even seem distant or ungrateful. But if I stayed, I’d break my commitment to myself, letting the noise and rush sweep away my calm. My heart thudded with guilt and longing, caught between the warmth of family and the quiet I craved.
